posts.post_text: May 5, 2018 at 1:22 PM#2You have to assign the off time to the executor, not the sequence.Example:Assign Executor 1.11 /offtime=1

posts.author: Duplicate bentoylight
posts.post_text: May 6, 2018 at 11:42 AM#3Do List Exec x.y or List Seq x to see all options and syntax in your command line feedback window.

posts.author: cn.liupei@live.com
posts.post_text: July 28, 2018 at 12:37 PM#5U Can try my macro<Macro index="1" name="Set Off Time"><Macroline index="0"><text>SetVar $lse=$selectedexec</text></Macroline><Macroline index="1"><text>Select Executor @</text></Macroline><Macroline index="2"><text>SetVar $offtime (OffTime)</text></Macroline><Macroline index="3"><text>Assign Executor $selectedexec /offtime=$offtime</text></Macroline><Macroline index="4"><text>Select Executor $lse</text></Macroline></Macro>

posts.post_text: August 5, 2018 at 5:13 PM#6Just create a macro with one line :assign /offtime=("off time ?") @
